chapter.title: Sequences and Series
chapter.introduction: To make sense of Riemann sums, we will first study sequences and series.

section.title: Sequences
section.p: Intuitively, a sequence is a list of numbers. More formally, a sequence \{a_n\}_{n \geq m} is the list of numbers a_m, a_{m+1}, a_{m+2}, \dots.

example.title: A Sequence
example.p: The sequence \{a_n\}_{n \geq 2} where a_n = 3n-4 is the sequnce below: 2, 5, 8, 11, 14, 17, \dots We might more often describe that sequence by declaring that a_n = 3n-4 for n \geq 2

chapter.title: Integration
chapter.p: This worksheet discusses material from section 1.1 of your book. We begin with some friendly review.

worksheet.title: Riemann Sums
worksheet.p: Recall that the definite integral of f on the closed interval [a,b] is \int_a^b f(x)\; dx = \lim_{n \to \infty} \sum_{i=1}^n f(x_i) \Delta x where \Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} and x_i = a + i \Delta x for i = 1, \dots, n. This definite integral represents the area under the curve f from a to b.
